header.p:
Here are some
lists pertaining to TV.

description.p: I watch TV on occasion. Actually, I don't exactly have the means to watch cable TV anymore since Comcast switched to a digital signal or whatever. That's all well and good because when I move out I'm not going to be getting cable service.

Personally, I think there's a lot of crap on TV today. I find it harder and harder to flip through the channels and find something I'm willing to watch at any given point during the day. That's bizarre, seeing as how there are more channels and more therefore more programming than there used to be. Why is there so much less to watch?

I think by far the worst crap on TV today are the shows that try to merge the styles of reality TV and documentary. Take Pawn Stars for example. I think that show is cool in concept. But it is clearly scripted, which is a disappointment. But what I hate about the show the most is the annoying cutaways to the mock interviews, in which the character is facing just off camera answering a question nobody asked in the most cliché way possible. That drives me CRAZY. And there are a ton of shows out there with the same format, and every one I've seen I've disliked.
Anyway, I usually just watch shows on TiVo. Here are some of my favorite shows.

listItem.columnValue: South Park

My favorite show on television. I love the satire and political/social commentary, but the fact that it's hilarious is certainly the show's greatest quality. I think I know about as much about this show as anyone.
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart

Thanks to the magic of TiVo, I didn't miss a single episode from fall 2005 to fall 2010--when I ended up going without cable for 8 months. I got back on the wagon around May 2011, but I've once again cut the cable cord, so I'll only be seeing it when I get the chance.

This show is bizzarely humorous. Louis C.K., head writer/director/producer, has an odd wit that is very easy to relate to, but his ideas are almost always pulled out of the stratosphere. This show breaks all the norms of a situational comedy.

This show is literally off the wall. It is full of non-sequiters and very often makes no sense whatsoever, but the absurdity adds to the hilarity. The characters (and the voice actors backing them) are consistently funny, especially Carl Brutananadilewski.
Family Guy
The best fart joke comedy TV has yet offered. However, its humor value has slipped in recent years. In general, the older the episode, the more I like it.
Law & Order

I've watched this show for years. Nowadays, it's a treat whenever an old episode comes on (such as one with Ben Stone), since after 19 seasons they tend to show more recent stuff. Jack McCoy is one of my favorite characters of all time.

description.p: I love South Park. Eventually I'm going to flesh this list out into a review website on the series, but that will take some time that I don't currently have. In the meantime, here are some of my favorite episodes and reasons why.
My favorite episodes tend to be favorites for some common reasons:

ol.li: Mostly set in the elementary school, dealing with just the kids and their lives

listItem.columnValue: Tweek vs. Craig

The Mr. Adler scenes are a little odd, I'll admit. But the premise of the fight, basically a bet between the main Four with Tweek and Craig caught in the middle, is hilarious. The sub-plot with Kenny taking home ec instead of shop class is also very fitting.
Jewbilee

I am actually a big Kenny fan, and in this episode, he has to fake being a Jew in order to go to a camp for Jewish kids with Kyle. I love the fact that you can clearly decipher what Kenny is saying without the other characters having to repeat it, as in other episodes. Even full sentences like "How do I do that?" are clear enough out of context to make sense. Moses is one of my favorite South Park characters; we see him later in Super Best Friends.
Cartman Joins NAMBLA

The fact that the show is plotted mainly around elementary school kids is generally one of the funniest building blocks of the show, because the naïveté opens up different ways to look at very seriously wrong things in the world, like NAMBLA. This episode exploits Cartman's naivety: he joins NAMBLA because he thinks he is too mature for his kid friends and these cool, older men welcome him in with open arms.
Towelie

This is probably the most self-aware episode of its time. A ridiculous, derp-quality character is introduced named Towelie, and he is by far "the worst character ever", but by that same token, he is also the best. During this whole episode the kids want nothing other than to get their Okama Game Sphere back so that they can continue playing Thirst for Blood, but in the meanwhile they have to suffer through one of the silliest, most contrived plot their writers have conceived yet!
Asspen

By this point in the series, the writers had successfully established a reputation for satire, to the point where they can write a satire about anything and nothing all at once. I can't tell if this episode is a direct satire of a specific story, or if it's just a wrapper for a bunch of lame stories with a similar storyline. Either way, the grief is clear, and anyone can relate.
Raisins

It is in this awesome episode that we first meet the Goth Kids, a group of which Stan briefly becomes a member. It's so sad watching Butters spend all his money on a slimey Raisins girl, but at the same time it is a vicious satire exposing the unfortunate thin line separating sexuality and good food service.
Quest for Ratings

columnValue.p: The kids are in some sort of TV production course and are producing a school news program. However, they find themselves losing in the ratings to Craig's "Animals Close Up With a Wide-Angle Lens", which is exactly what it sounds like. So they beef up their news program with flashy graphics, lies about celebrities, and stories that make people feel like they have to watch the show or they'll die (just like real news programs).
It's even funnier to note that Trey Parker said of this episode, "...this was the first time we were officially...out of ideas." Oh the irony.

listItem.columnValue: The Losing Edge

columnValue.p: The kids are all playing baseball all summer in the state tournament circuit, and they hate every minute of it. They want to lose so that their season will end, but every other team in the league wants the same thing. The teams find themselves battling to see who can lose. An ingenious take on kids sports.

The parents, on the other hand, love every minute of their kids' success, especially Randy, who always gets into fights with other drunk dads at the games. He is speechless to find out that he is going to get to fight in the State Championship game.

listItem.columnValue: With Apologies to Jesse Jackson

columnValue.p: The first and second times I watched this episode (different audiences), everyone in the room found themselves gasping for air after laughing uncontrollably at the opening sequence. What an INCREDIBLE season premiere to have seen with all of my friends in our freshman year apartment.

listItem.columnValue: The List
Another episode based almost solely around just the kids and their lives at the elementary school. That's not the only reason I like it, but it's a good reason. Does that sparkle with you?
Major Boobage

This episode has so much to offer: Kenny doing drugs (sniffing cat pee), Cartman keeping a safe-house during the cat holocaust, an Eliot Spitzer-themed public apology performed by Gerold Broflovski, and a Heavy Metal parody, both in music and animation. I love it when Butters tries to comfort Kenny while he detoxes.
The Ungroundable

This episode forces you to relate to the Goth kids, of all people, in their contempt for "Vamp" kids--kids who think it's cool to dress up like vampires. With the recent vampire craze, for those of us thinking, "seriously, what's the deal?", this episode shines brightly through the dark with a clear message: anyone who likes to dress up like a vampire is a douchebag. Here, the writers again play on the naïveté of the characters, specifically Butters. Butters is "transformed" into a vampire and doesn't realize that he's still in fact a human, and goes without food because he thinks he needs to consume only blood. He even goes so far as to give Cartman a hickey trying to suck his blood, never having even bitten into him.
Pinewood Derby

The opening sequence of Stan and Randy preparing for and subsequently winning the Pinewood Derby is probably my favorite beginning to any South Park episode, with the opening to "With Apologies to Jesse Jackson" being a very close second. I love the scene when the FBI first comes to visit Randy.
You Have 0 Friends
Nothing has ever sufficed in expressing my hatred of Facebook better than this episode. It is also brilliantly written. In this episode, I am Stan. And to quote Stan, "Fuck Facebook, seriously!"
